titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Black Students Alliance records CA.MS.00308
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Yasmine Evans, Amanda Lineweber

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-03-13 10:07:00 -0400.

change.item: This resource was modified by the ArchivesSpace Preprocessor developed by the Harvard Library (https://github.com/harvard-library/archivesspace-preprocessor)

did.abstract: This collection contains notebooks, correspondence, conference materials, minutes, photographs, and event fliers documenting the Black Students Alliance.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The earliest records of the Black Students Alliance (BSA) date from 1970, when black students and faculty across the Five Colleges formed a committee to demand the inclusion of Afro-American Studies in Five College curriculums. Smith's BSA became active soon afterward, first with protests concerning the state of Afro-American Studies at Smith and then with student newsletters and events. In 1974 the BSA ran a children's fair at the Mwangi Cultural Center, then located in Lily Hall. The goal of the fair was to educate local children about black cultural heritage. The BSA's annual events have included a Black Arts Festival, Black History Observance events, cultural events such as Kwanza and musical performers, social events including parties and movie nights for both BSA members and the larger campus community. The BSA has also participated regularly in local black students' conferences. Additionally, the BSA has been partially in charge of Unity House and the Mwangi Cultural Center with the cultural center staff since its creation in the 1970s, and an active participant in planning and running Bridge, an annual pre-orientation program for students of color.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records of the BSA include general and officers' notebooks which contain a variety of materials, including notes, minutes, correspondence, budget sheets, event fliers, reports, and more.

The records also contain files of minutes and correspondence concerning the Mwangi Cultural Center, the Five College Executive Committee on Afro-American Studies, Smith College's Afro-American Studies Department, and the annual black student's conference. There are also a few files of BSA newsletters and other assorted correspondence.
Most of the photographs are unidentified and undated. They are mainly of various BSA members and events.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into thirteen series:

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Smith College retains copyright of materials created as part of its business operations; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Smith College, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Black Students Alliance records, Smith College Archives, CA-MS-00308, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The records of the Black Students Alliance were donated over a period of time to the Smith College Archives from a variety of sources.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Yasmine Evans, Class of 2013; Amanda Lineweber, Class of 2011
